discussion.content: E, not C. C is a case-sensitive check.

Selected Answer: E
E is correct, C would fail only if it would be written with any lower case character but the way it's given here makes it valid

But C would be wrong if was executed with case sensitive letters, for example:
EXEC get_tab_row_count (‘ "Emp" ’);

questions.question_text:
You are logged on to the SCOTT schema and the schema has EMP and DEPT tables already created:
Examine this PL/SQL procedure:
//IMG//

Which PL/SQL block will raise an exception?

discussion.content: A and D should be correct answers

Selected Answer: AD
AD should be the correct choices, the question deals with implicit conversions and the resulting differences
I think is B and C.

A and D
Some possible solutions to this problem are:

Change the return type of get_hire_date to DATE and have each session invoke the TO_CHAR function.

If a common format is acceptable to all sessions, specify a format mask, removing the dependency on NLS_DATE_FORMAT. For example:

TO_CHAR(date_hired, 'mm/dd/yy');
Add a format mask parameter to get_hire_date. For example:

CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION get_hire_date
 (emp_id NUMBER, fmt VARCHAR) RETURN VARCHAR
 RESULT_CACHE
IS
 date_hired DATE;
BEGIN
 SELECT hire_date INTO date_hired
 FROM HR.EMPLOYEES
 WHERE EMPLOYEE_ID = emp_id;
 RETURN TO_CHAR(date_hired, fmt);
END;
/

choices.A: Add a parameter, fmt, and change the RETURN statement to: RETURN TO_CHAR (date_hired, fmt);
choices.D: Change the return type of GET_HIRE_DATE to DATE and have each session invoke the TO_CHAR function.
choices.C: Increase the value for the RESULT_CACHE_MAX_SIZE parameter.
choices.B: Set the RESULT_CACHE_MODE parameter to FORCE.

questions.question_text:
This result cache is enabled for the database instance.
Examine this code for a PL/SQL function:
//IMG//

Which two actions would ensure that the same result will be consistently returned for any session when the same input value is passed to the function?
Which two statements are correct in Oracle Database 12c?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
Default Compilation mode: interpreted

comments.content:
sorry, D,E are correct. 
C is false because of "As a good practice, you may want to compile-interpreted during the regular development cycle and compile-native when development IS COMPLETE" and not during. ref -> https://www.oracle.com/technical-resources/articles/database/sql-11g-plsql.htmlhttps://www.oracle.com/technical-resources/articles/database/sql-11g-plsql.html

choices.E: To change a PL/SQL object from interpreted to native code, set the PLSQL_CODE_TYPE to NATIVE and recompile it.
choices.B: Native compilation is the default compilation method
choices.C: Native compilation should be used during development.
choices.A: For native compilation, PLSQL_OPTIMIZE_LEWVEL should be set to 2.
choices.D: Natively compiles code is stored in the SYSTEM tablespace.

choices.B: It will fail compile because of errors at lines 6 and 12.
choices.D: It will fail compile and execute successfully.
choices.C: It will fail compile because of error at line 7.
choices.E: It will fail compile because of errors at lines 5 and 6.
choices.A: It will fail compile because of errors at lines 11 and 12.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct

B is correct answer: 
Line 6 gives error because constructor should be nested_type, so this line should be: n_table1 nested_typ := nested_typ('AB1','AB2','AB3')
Line 12: you can assign 2 VARRAY variables only if they have matching data types, not matching data types of elements (varchar2(15)).
